mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Musical Borrowing and Its Meaning in Lera Auerbach's Ludwigs Alptraum and Clifton Callender's À la manière de

mods:mods.mods:abstract: This treatise will examine two contemporary piano works, Lera Auerbach's Ludwigs Alptraum (2007) and Clifton Callender's à la manière de (2018). Both pieces deliberately include references to the music of particular traditions and compositional styles as well as unique musical languages in rhythm, harmony, texture, and form. The classically trained ears would easily recognize the musical quotations but the quotations are not always as expected as the received effect. For example, Auerbach extracts completely different expressions out of the exact same material, by putting it in a new context; Callender alludes to multiple influences within a single pastiche which often contradict one another. Moreover, even though they have overtly referred to specific styles or works, their experimental musical languages can obscure the quotation itself and its meaning. The received meaning from the borrowed materials helps the listener figure out the possible meanings and interpretations of the new pieces. The listener may also find another meaning in the existing passage in the new context and new language. The interpretation of musical borrowing in these pieces can be more open, inclusive, and subjective by individual listeners. The purpose of the analysis is to reveal the possible meaning within the unfamiliar musical language of the new pieces. The idea of intertextuality is adapted to the analyses, to the extent of employing multiple texts to make sense of a new musical text. Theories of intertextuality claim that a reader always brings other texts to an understanding of the single text, so that all writing is filled with allusions, quotations, and references to other writing. It is a postmodern thought that presents multiple meanings and temporalities. The intertextual musical analysis in this paper models on Michael Leslie Klein's Intertextuality in Western Art Music (Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 2004). The intertextual application is to understand difficult passages in new musical styles of two contemporary composers, rather than to compare the pieces with the knowingly or unknowingly quoted resources. By examining the quoted melodies, alluded styles, and structural similarity from the intertwined references, one can reason the composer's intent and implied meaning of the piece through reconceptualization and interpretation of the passages in question. It will help performers and listeners to understand, interpret, and accept the new languages and styles presented in these pieces more easily and effectively.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
Ian Hobson, Professor Co-Directing Treatise; Read Gainsford, Professor Co-Directing Treatise; Jane Piper Clendinning, University Representative; Stijn De Cock, Committee Member.
